# Frequency polygons {.unnumbered} ::: {.callout-tip appearance='simple' icon=false} ***This graph is largely complete and just needs final proof reading.*** ::: :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false} ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #02577A;"} Graph info :::
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](frequency_polygons_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #02577A;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #282b2d;"} **✅ a numeric (continuous) variable** ::: :::: ## Description Frequency polygons are similar to histograms, but they use lines instead of bars to represent the variable's distribution. The height of the line represents the frequency (or count) of the value occurrence. When viewing frequency polygons, we're still assessing the shape of the lines for [symmetry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_distribution) and [skewness.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skewness). ## Getting set up :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Packages ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Install packages. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by Allison Horst](www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} The `penguins` data ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins glimpse(penguins) #> Rows: 344 #> Columns: 8 #> $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, … #> $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen,… #> $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3… #> $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6… #> $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181… #> $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650… #> $ sex male, female, female, NA, female… #> $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 20… ``` ::: ::: :::: ## The grammar :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Code ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Create labels with `labs()` Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` Map `flipper_length_mm` to the `x` axis Add the `geom_freqpoly()` layer ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_freqpoly <- labs( title = "Adult foraging penguins", subtitle = "Distribution of flipper length", x = "Flipper length (millimeters)") ggp2_freqpoly <- ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm)) + geom_freqpoly() ggp2_freqpoly + labs_freqpoly ``` ::: ::: ### Graph ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](frequency_polygons_files/figure-html/create_graph_freq_poly-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Experiment to see how many `bins` fit your variable’s distribution ::: ::::
